The catalytic oxidation of carbon monoxide (CO) by manganese oxide catalysts has always been a research hotspot. In complex sintering flue gas environments, chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) with high toxicity, volatility, and recalcitrance have a significant impact on the CO oxidation activity of catalysts. In this investigation, dichloromethane (DCM) was used as a model pollutant to study the effect of CVOCs on CO catalytic oxidation reaction for the first time. The preparation of Cu0.25/MnO2 using the oxalic acid chelation-assisted hydrothermal method showed the best CO removal efficiency and chlorine resistance. Cu promoted the generation of oxygen vacancies by enhancing electron transfer, which was beneficial for slowing down the adsorption of chlorine species on active sites. The introduction of Cu lowers the desorption temperature of HCl and inhibit the reversible adsorption of chlorine species. Through the use of in-situ DRIFT and other physical and chemical techniques, it was found that the mechanism of catalyst deactivation is staged. (1) Short-term deactivation: DCM adsorbed on oxygen vacancies, temporarily covering the active sites. (2) Long-term deactivation: DCM decomposed to produce chlorine species, which form stable Cl metal species with the metal. The mechanism by which copper doping enhanced the chlorine resistance of catalysts has been clarified, providing new insights into improving the chlorine resistance of catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO oxidation DCM Poisoning mechanism Sintering flue gas Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As the main industrial emission source, the steel smelting process in the steel industry emits a large amount of sintering flue gas [1]. The composition of sintering flue gas is complex and includes a variety of pollutants, such as CO and CVOCs. The presence of CO in sintering flue gas can be attributed to incomplete combustion of the fuel. Its concentration is approximately 1 vol %, as determined by analysis [2]. CO, as a long-term toxic gas, poses a threat to the environment and human health [3]. Strict regulations have been proposed by several nations to address gaseous pollutants in the steel sector [4]. However, the treatment of sintering flue gas is hindered by the presence of certain CVOCs, which exhibit high volatility, difficulty in degradation and high toxicity. Consequently, a comprehensive study is essential to investigate the impact of CVOCs on CO catalytic oxidation in a flue gas atmosphere with a high concentration of sintering particles. In the field of CO purification treatment technology, the two most prevalent approaches are photocatalytic and thermal catalytic technologies. Low conversion efficiency hinders the use of photocatalytic technology in industry [5]. Conversely, catalytic oxidation in thermal technology is currently regarded as the most energy-efficient and effective method for CO purification [6]. The design of catalysts is crucial for CO catalytic oxidation reactions, among which metal oxide catalysts have always been of great concern. Noble metals like Pt [7], Pd [8], Au [9], and Ru [10] are still certain challenges to be overcome in industrial applications. In comparison, transition metal catalysts, including Mn [11], Cu [12] and Fe [13], demonstrate greater potential such as low-cost, can easily access to raw materials, and adsorb O2 adsorption at low temperatures for industrial applications [14]. Mn-based catalysts have been the subject of considerable research interest due to a number of favorable properties, including corrosion resistance, rich oxidation valence states, polycrystalline phases, and good catalytic performance. Manganese oxide catalysts' oxidation performance directly correlates with their structural configurations and polymorphic properties. Among various structures, the rod-shaped morphology exhibits superior catalytic advantages due to its unique tunnel size [15]. In contrast to linear, tubular, and flower-shaped nanorods, Wang et al. [16] found α-MnO2 nanorods produced by burning toluene demonstrated optimal oxygen mobility, low-temperature reducibility, and increased oxygen vacancy (OV) density. This phenomenon is due to the significant influence of crystallization on the valence state of manganese and the kinetics of OV formation. Sun et al. [15] also demonstrated, out of the common polymorphs (α, β, and γ), α- MnO2 has the largest tunnel size. The systematic comparison of the structural characteristics showed that α-MnO2 dominated the BET surface area (131 m2/g, 125 m2/g for γ-MnO2 and 67 m2/g for β-MnO2), pore volume (0.36 cm3/g) and mean pore size (8.8 nm) [17]. These parameters synergistically enhance the adsorption and diffusion kinetics of CVOCs. Song et al. [18] verified the thermal stability by calculation, which is another key factor in the catalytic lifetime. Because α-MnO2 had stronger atomic cohesion than β-MnO2, they discovered that the energy barrier for the decomposition of the former was 3.67 % higher. Notably, during CO oxidation, it has been demonstrated the lattice oxygen mobility in α-MnO2 nanorods was twice that of β-MnO2 nanorod [19]. Sumanta et al. [20]'s in-situ spectroscopic investigation verified that it could activate oxygen species at lower temperatures by utilizing a large number of metastable OV. These common physicochemical properties make α-MnO2 nanorods an ideal model system for exploring CVOCs-induced deactivation mechanisms. Doping Cu into MnO2 can maximize the oxygen vacancy content and oxygen migration rate. Zheng et al. [21] found that Cu could enhance the activity of transition metal doped heterogeneous catalysts by promoting electron transfer. Li et al. [22] found through computational simulations that in Co3O4, Cu brings the D-band center closer to the Fermi level, generates abundant oxygen vacancies, and promotes the reconstruction of the catalyst to form. So, adding a Cu catalyst system to α-MnO2 will enhance the high activity, selectivity, and stability of CO catalytic oxidation. However, CVOCs in flue gas can damage manganese based catalysts at low temperatures, causing irreversible damage [23]. Understanding the mechanism of chlorine poisoning is helpful for studying the chlorine resistance of catalysts and increasing their application value. Mn-based catalysts can be deactivated by CVOCs in three main ways. (a) Lin et al. [24] found Cl₂ and other species containing chlorine adsorb onto the catalyst surface. This blocked active sites and inhibiting the activation of CCl in CVOCs. (b) Weng et al. [25] found that as catalysts aged, they became less selective in oxidizing CVOCs. Cl got adsorbed on the surface more easily. The catalyst deactivated as a result of severe carbon deposition brought on by the buildup of intermediates. (c)Zhang et al. [26] explained chloride could adsorb on acidic and oxygen vacancies, which broke the redox cycle between the Mn4+ and Mn3+ oxidation states. These leaves fewer sites available for chloride oxidation. In summary, the impact of chlorine poisoning on Mn based catalysts is very complex. This study first examines the specific circumstances that result in the excellent performance of α-MnO2 being compromised in a sintering flue gas atmosphere that contains CVOCs. On this basis, further analysis is conducted to ascertain the specific reasons for the poisoning of rod-shaped α-MnO2 catalysts. Additionally, the relationship between the existence of lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancies and the chlorine adsorption sites of the catalyst's chlorination reaction is identified. Finally, the specific effects of introducing Cu on the poisoning of the catalyst are investigated, and the interaction between Cu and Mn on the oxygen vacancies and chlorine adsorption sites in the catalyst is elucidated when Cu was introduced into the Mn framework. This offers a theoretical framework for further investigation into the enhancement of the catalyst's chlorine resistance. 2 Experimental sections 2.1 Preparation process of materials and catalysts Based on the methodology previously established by Zhang et al. [27], the hydrothermal approach was used to synthesize the rod-shaped MnO2 and Cux/ MnO2 catalyst(x = 0, 0.1, 0.25, 1 %, molar ratio). The specific proportion can be found in Support Information. Preparation of rod-shaped MnO2: A specific amount of KMnO4 and (NH4)2C2O4 were dissolved in a 2:1 molar ratio. Transfer the mixture to a PTFE-lined reactor after stirring until complete dissolution. Perform a 24-hour hydrothermal treatment in a homogeneous reactor at a reaction temperature of 180 °C. Cool to room temperature, wash with anhydrous ethanol and deionized water. Place the sample in an oven at 105 °C to dry overnight. Rod-shaped MnO2 was prepared by calcining at 350 °C for 2 h in an air atmosphere. Preparation of rod-shaped Cux/MnO2: Add Cu (NO3)2•3H2O to the prepared solution and follow the same procedure. 2.2 Catalytic evaluation To assess CO oxidation activity, place the sample in a fixed bed quartz tube reactor. Use 0.6 g of catalyst (40–60 mesh) and an 8 mm quartz tube. Replicate these flue gas conditions: 4000 ppm CO, 16 vol % O2, 500 ppm DCM, and Ar as a balance gas. The total flow is 500 ml/min and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) is 20,000 h-1. T The concentrations of all components are monitored online by a portable infrared smoke analyzer (DX-4000). The conversion rate of CO is calculated as Eq. (1): (1) CO conversion = [ CO ] in − [ CO ] out [ CO ] in × 100 % Make sure the reaction takes place between 100 and 260 °C by using a thermocouple to measure the reaction temperature. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The BET (Brunauer Emmett Teller) method was used to calculate the specific surface area and determine the isothermal adsorption curve of the N2 adsorption/desorption catalyst. The BJH (Barret Joyner Halenda) method was used to calculate the pore size distribution. XRD was used to analyze the crystal phase composition of the catalyst. The catalyst's crystal structure was analyzed with X-rays at the Bruck D8 ADVANCE diffractometer. XPS analysis of chemical composition and valence states was used an Al light source (1486.6 eV HV) as the radiation source. The binding energy of all elements was calibrated to C1s = 284.8 eV. Utilize HRTEM to study the catalyst's microstructure and lattice arrangement. Disperse the sample on a Cu mesh after ultrasonic treatment prior to measurement. TG-MS were conducted on SETSYS Evolution TGA 16/18, SETARAM, France. The tests parameters were: 50–850 °C, 5 °C/min, N2 and 50–1000 °C, 2 °C/min. Before using CIC-D160 ion chromatography (IC), dissolve the sample in a solution of oxalic acid and concentrated sulfuric acid. The testing of H2-TPR and O2-TPD was conducted on Quantachrome ChemStar. The H2-TPR test conditions were: a U-shaped tube with 30 mg of the sample treated with Ar at 300 °C. Then, 10 % H₂/Ar was added at 50 °C and the temperature increased to 800 °C slowly. Test conditions for O2-TPD were: A U-shaped tube was treated at 300 °C with He, then heated to 50 °C with O2/He. The temperature was increased to 825 °C with N2. The characterization of NH3-TPD was carried out on Belcat in Japan. Test conditions for NH3-TPD were: 100 mg sample was pretreated with He at 300 °C for 1 h, and 10 % NH3/He was introduced at 50 °C. The temperature was raised to 450 °C at 10 °C/min. EPR characterization was performed using Bruke EMXPLIS from Germany, with a test power of 3.17 mW, a scanning width of 100 G, a scanning time of 60 s, and a frequency of 100 kHz. Use the Bruker Tensor 27 to analyze the reaction process of the catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity and toxicity Fig. 1(a) illustrated the catalytic performance of catalysts with different copper doping levels (Cu/Mn = 0, 0.1, 0.25, 1 %, molar ratio). The catalyst with a molar ratio of Cu/Mn = 0.25 % exhibited the best CO catalytic oxidation activity at low temperatures. A Cu/Mn ratio of 0.25 % was chosen for the ensuing DCM poisoning tests. As shown in Fig. 1(b), the catalyst was poisoned by transient experiments using DCM as the pollutant. After stabilizing at 200 °C for 2 h, 500 ppm DCM was introduced to observe the activity changes of the catalyst. MnO2 carbon monoxide conversion decreased significantly from 100 % to about 53 %, stabilizing at 57 %. Cu0.25/MnO2 peaked at 72 % and stabilizes at 74 %. Fig. 1(c) illustrated the stability test under actual operating conditions (50 ppm DCM). The high stability of the catalyst was demonstrated by the CO conversion rate (>95 %). Fig. 1(d) illustrated the effect of 10 % H2O on the catalytic poisoning process. When water was added, the activity of the catalyst returned immediately after it had dropped for 20 h. This indicated that low concentrations of water inhibited catalyst poisoning. Fig.S1 illustrated the poisoning process of CVOCs at different concentrations and temperatures. The significant dependence of the catalyst on reaction temperature was demonstrated, while exhibiting slow deactivation kinetics under real operating conditions. 3.2 Physical and chemical property analysis 3.2.1 Structural analysis of catalyst Utilizing XRD analysis, examine the catalyst's changes in crystal phase structure. Fig. 2 illustrated the results of the analysis. Cu0.25/MnO2 and MnO2 were observed to have similar characteristic peaks, which were in good agreement with the standard XRD map (JCPDS PDF# 72–1982) of standard α-MnO2. Cu0.25/MnO2 and MnO2 catalysts were highly crystalline. The strongest and sharpest peak shape in the diffraction peak signal was located at approximately 28° This suggested that the (310) surface was the primary exposed surface of the synthesized α-MnO2. The Bragg equation states that when the unit cell grows or shrinks, the diffraction angle's magnitude correspondingly changes. Diffraction angles of Cu0.25/MnO2 slightly shifted to left compared to MnO2 (28.77 → 28.67, 37.59 → 37.36, 56.77 → 56.66, 60.08 → 59.43). It indicated that Cu was doped into the Mn framework [28]. The lack of distinctive copper or copper oxide diffraction peaks indicated that either the catalyst's copper content was too low to be detected or Cu was widely distributed on the surface [29]. The crystal structure remained unchanged after Cu was added. Since there was no evidence of copper oxide lattice spacing on the catalyst, copper oxide is primarily found in an amorphous state. Fig. 3 illustrated the HRTEM results of catalysts MnO2 and Cu0.25/MnO2. According to Fig. 3 (a) and (b), the catalysts were both rod-shaped structures. As shown in Fig. 3 (c) and (d), the lattice spacing of three crystal planes was displayed on the rod-shaped structure: they belonged to the (110) crystal plane with d ≈ 6.94 nm, the (310) crystal plane with d ≈ 3.10 nm, and the (121) crystal plane with d ≈ 2.39 nm, respectively. These results corresponded to the diffraction peak results of XRD. According to Fig. 3 (e), with no discernible Cu nanoclusters or nanoparticles on the catalyst surface, because of the high dispersion of Cu on MnO2. As illustrated in Fig. 3(e) and (f), the catalyst maintained nanorod-like structure even in the aftermath of chlorine poisoning. It was suggested that the cause of the poisoning could be a shift in the chemical properties of the catalyst. Fig. 4 displayed the N2 adsorption/desorption curve and pore size distribution curve of the catalyst (illustrated). The specific surface area (SBET), pore volume (VP), and mean pore size (DBJH) of catalysts were all impacted by DCM influences. Cu addition slightly increased the catalytic inhibition of DCM. Langmuir IV type curves accompanied by H1 hysteresis loops were observed for the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of all catalysts. Pore size distributions were concentrated around 10 nm, indicating a mesoporous material. Using Table 1 , determine the SBET, VP, and DBJH. SBET of catalysts significantly affected by DCM. Following the DCM reaction, the SBET of MnO2 dropped by 41.2 % (146.77 → 86.35), while the SBET of Cu0.25/MnO2 dropped by 22.4 % (137.32 → 106.48). The change in the SBET of MnO2 was roughly twice as large as Cu0.25/MnO2. The specific surface area of the catalyst was reduced by the addition of Cu. DCM also affected the VP of catalysts. The VP of MnO2 dropped by 36.2 % (0.47 → 0.3), but the VP of Cu0.25/MnO2 dropped by only 8.5 % (0.47 → 0.43). In relation to the addition of Cu, the BET results showed that the VP of the catalyst doped with Cu varies very little. MnO2 DBJH increased by 7.5 % (12.89 → 13.86), while Cu0.25/MnO2 went up 18 % (13.55 → 16). 3.3 XPS analysis Utilizing XPS, examine the surface chemical states and variations in the catalyst's elemental composition following various reactions. Fig. 5 displayed the deconvolution outcomes for XPS spectra of Mn 2p3/2, Mn 3 s, O 1 s, and Cl 2p As shown in Table 2 and Table 3 , the percentage of different Mn valence states, Oads, Olat, and Cl in the fitting results. Fig. 5(a) and Fig. 5(b) displayed the Mn 2p3/2 spectra of the catalyst. The peak binding energies ranged from 640.79 to 641.19 eV, 641.93 to 642.24 eV, and 642.85 to 643.42 eV, respectively. These values were corresponded to the binding energies of Mn2+[30], Mn3+[31], and Mn4+[32] on the catalyst surface. In contrast, the fresh catalyst doped with Cu had the largest Mn3+ proportion (49.13 %). According to Hu et al. [28], this because the catalyst's capacity to generate and recover Mn3+ during the reaction was improved by the addition of Cu. Fig. S2 showed the XPS data fitting and analysis related to the activity and chlorine resistance of the catalyst. As shown in Fig.S2 (a), when AOS increases from 3.44 to 3.66 and the Mn 3+/Mn 4+ ratio increases from 0.93 to 1.46, both show a significant negative correlation with T50 parameter. As shown in Fig.S2 (b), when the Mn 3+ content increased by 1.2 times and the Oads ratio increased by 1.01 times, the catalytic system's resistance to chlorine poisoning was significantly enhanced (conversion rate increased by 19 %). The catalyst's Mn 3 s deconvolution spectra were displayed in Fig. 5(c) and Fig. 5(d). Compute the average oxidation state (AOS) by fitting the binding energy difference (ΔEs) of the spectrum using formula Eq. (2) [33]. (2) AOS = 8 . 956 − 1 . 126 * Δ E s Fresh catalyst had AOS values of 3.66 (Cu0.25/MnO2) and 3.44 (MnO2), respectively. The catalyst's redox ability is positively correlated with its AOS value [34]. The AOS value also decreased to varying degrees as various reactions progressed. However, Cu0.25/MnO2's AOS value continuously surpassed MnO2's, supporting the notion that the catalyst had strong oxidizing properties. Fig. 5(e) and Fig. 5(f) showed the O 1 s spectra of the catalyst. Fitting yielded two peaks: one related to surface lattice oxygen species (Olat)[35] in the range of 529.62–529.85 eV, and the other to surface adsorbed oxygen species (Oads)[36] in the range of 531.31–533.22 eV. Prior to the reaction, the Cu0.25/MnO2 catalyst had a higher Olat content than MnO2. Cao et al. [37] found that doping Cu could enhance the mobility of Olat, thereby improving the activity of the catalyst. He et al. [38] believed that Oads was positively correlated with oxygen vacancy density. Oads's ability to absorb and activate gas-phase oxygen in the oxygen cycle increases with its concentration. The Oads ratio of fresh catalyst (Cu0.25/MnO2: 33.46 %, MnO2: 33.01 %) were around 33 %, which mean Oads / Olat ≈ 0.5. Indicating that there were more oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalyst, which was beneficial for improving catalytic activity The catalyst consumed a large amount of Olat (Oads /Olat≈1.38) when poisoning DCM. Oads binding energy dramatically increased (Cu0.25/MnO2: 0.71 eV, MnO2: 1.07 eV). Li et al. [39] concluded that at this point the electron cloud density on the catalyst surface decreased in the vicinity of the oxygen. This indicated a reduction in the activity of the catalyst. The Cl 2p spectra of the catalyst were presented in Fig. 5(g) and Fig. 5(h). The peak binding energy range was from 198.39 to 198.57 eV for inorganic chlorine species in metal oxides (Clmetal) and from 200.01 to 200.22 eV for organic chlorine species (Clorganic) [40]. As shown in Table 3, Clorganic/Clmetal≈0.51, was a similar proportion of Cl species on different catalyst surfaces. This indicated that the catalyst surface had accumulated a large amount of chlorine species. Chlorine-containing species can interact with metal elements to form Clmetal during the MxOyCl (M stands for metals) reaction. Cl species that are difficult to remove and that gradually accumulate on the catalyst surface, leading to toxicity and inactivation, may cause catalyst inactivation. According to the method of Bertinchamps et al. [41], the atomic ratio of elements was calculated by fitting the peak area and sensitivity factor of XPS. Fig. S3 showed the ratio of organic and metallic Cl to Mn on the catalyst surface. Table 3 showed the results of the calculations. On 140 Mn atoms, one Cl atom could be deposited, according to the Cl/Mn ratio of 0.0072 in the Cu0.25/MnO2 catalyst. The MnO2 catalyst has approximately 90 Mn atoms corresponding to 1 Cl atom. This suggested that Cl deposition could readily deactivate Mn catalyst. Cu significantly decreased the likelihood that Cl will deposit Mn, the catalyst's active ingredient. 3.4 EPR analysis The use of EPR spectroscopy enabled the confirmation of the presence of oxygen vacancies (Ov) in the catalyst surface, as illustrated in Fig. 6(a) . g = 2.003, suggesting that the catalyst's crystal structure contains oxygen vacancies [42]. By observing the black and blue signal peaks, it was found that Cu0.25/MnO2 exhibited higher peaks in the catalyst before the reaction. This indicated that the introduction of Cu can increase the number of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst. By observing the red and green signal peaks, it was found that the catalyst (Cl)Cu0.25/MnO2 exhibited the same trend after poisoning reaction. The intensity of both signal peaks of the catalyst significantly decreased after poisoning, indicating that oxygen vacancies were occupied during the poisoning reaction. 3.5 NH3-TPD analysis Analyze the surface acidity of the poisoned catalyst through NH3-TPD. Fig. 6(b) showed the results and Table 4 presents the corresponding acidity values. All samples showed weak acids at temperatures below 250 °C [43]. The NH3 desorption amount of the catalyst significantly increases after poisoning. This indicated that the HCl generated by DCM during the reaction process was deposited on the surface of the catalyst. After poisoning, Cu0.25/MnO2 was much less acidic than MnO2. Cu reduced the adsorption capacity of HCl species, slowing down deactivation of the catalyst. The location of desorption peak (about 200 °C) indicated that it is a B acid [44]. This shift results from the catalyst surface's abundant surface active oxygen, which had the capacity to take in more H atoms for separation from DCM and the formation of more -OH groups on the catalyst surface [45]. A decrease in Mn3+ was observed in the XPS results of the pure MnO2 catalyst following the poisoning reaction, which was in line with the EPR's observation of a decrease in oxygen vacancies. This reflected a decrease in Lewis acid sites, indicating the presence of DCM adsorption on the catalyst surface [44]. 3.6 Analysis of chlorine containing substances Ion chromatography (IC) determination of Cl in catalyst after DCM reaction. The obtained calculation results were shown in Fig. 6(c). Accordingly, MnO2's resistance to chlorine poisoning was somewhat increased by adding copper, which was consistent with the previous XPS finding. By using TG-MS analysis, the particular kinds of chlorides that could be produced in the catalyst following chlorine poisoning were identified. The corresponding substance could be identified as HCl based on the starting temperature of the signal peak during detection being <100 °C (Cu0.25/MnO2: 74.83 °C, MnO2: 79.48 °C) and m/z = 37. Fig. 6(d) showed the variation of HCl content in the poisoned catalyst with temperature, and the calculated peak area was shown in Table 4. Peak area size used to assess difficulty of catalyst poisoning by DCM. Peak area of HCl on MnO2 was 1.89 times that of Cu0.25/MnO2 (Fig. 6(d) ). 3.7 Redox analysis H2-TPR to study reducibility and catalytic activity of surface oxides. The fresh catalyst's peak did not change significantly after taking part in the CO oxidation reaction, as shown in Fig. 7(a) and (b). Liu et al. [46] concluded that the reduction of CuO, Cu2O, and free Cu2+ on the catalyst surface was thought to be responsible for the lower temperature (226 °C, 246 °C) reduction peaks that were observed. Similar to the findings of Li et al. [47]., the reduction peak at 259 °C could be attributed to hydrogen gas overflowing to the MnOx interface after a rapid reduction reaction with Cu. Chen et al. [48]. reported states that the reduction of MnOx was responsible for the reduction peak that appears at >300 °C. From low to high, the reduction reactions of MnO2 → Mn3O4 [49] and MnO2 → Mn2O3 [50] occurred in the first reduction peak (Cu0.25/MnO2: 314 °C and MnO2: 327 °C), while the reduction reactions of Mn3O4 → MnO [51] and Mn2O3 → MnO [52] occurred in the second reduction peak. The catalyst doped with a small amount of Cu had a reduction peak temperature at least 60 °C lower than the undoped catalyst, according to a comparison of the reduction peak temperatures of the two catalysts. The difference of 60 °C indicated that the doping of Cu in the catalyst could reduce the temperature delay of Mn4+ reduction, which to some extent protected the Mn valence state cycle of the catalyst and improved its reducibility. The distribution of the main peaks in the two red curves was the reduction of Mn2O3 → Mn3O4 [53]. After poisoning, the temperature of the main peak of the two catalysts shifted significantly to the right. The significant difference in the main peak positions of the two lines was mainly related to the adsorption degree of Cl species at high temperatures. Gao et al. [54] suggested that when Cl species strongly adsorb onto MnOx catalysts at high temperatures, it lead to a delay in the temperature range of Mn4+ reduction. This is consistent with our results. Table ST2 showed that the hydrogen consumed by the catalyst increases dramatically following poisoning. Using O2-TPD to examine the oxygen species' activation potential and rate of migration on catalysts. The results were shown in Fig. 7(c) and (d). The O2-TPD desorption peak [55] was classified as bulk lattice oxygen (O2-), surface lattice oxygen (O-), and chemically adsorbed oxygen (O2 -) based on its temperature range. The desorption peak temperatures were all above 550 °C. According to Deng et al. [56], the desorption peak above 400 °C was the desorption of O-, while the desorption peak above 650 °C was the desorption of O2-. As shown in Fig. 7(c) and (d), the desorption peaks of surface lattice oxygen (O-) and bulk lattice oxygen (O2-) of Cu doped catalysts and pure manganese catalysts did not change significantly before and after the CO oxidation reaction. (Cu0.25/MnO2:587 °C →581 °C; 785 °C → 781 °C. MnO2: 568 °C →590 °C; 752 °C → 778 °C). Hua et al. [57] found that a high lattice oxygen content help to increase the rate at which oxygen migrates, which in turn speed up oxidation reactions. Table ST1 demonstrated a notable decline in the catalyst's oxygen desorption content in response to poisoning. Catalyst poisoning and deactivation were caused by a decrease in lattice oxygen fluidity and a decrease in catalyst activity. The desorption peak of bulk lattice oxygen in the red curve shifted to the right. This indicated that the activation energy of lattice oxygen in the catalyst increases, resulting in higher temperatures required for oxygen desorption, making it more difficult for it to migrate to the surface [58]. Combined with H2-TPR analysis, this indicated that the mobility of lattice oxygen decreases and the activity of the catalyst decreases after poisoning. This corresponded to changes in hydrogen consumption. 3.8 In-situ DRIFTs studies 3.8.1 Adsorption on catalysts Analyze the mechanism of catalyst poisoning and deactivation through in-situ DRIFT analysis. Table 5 showed the specific absorption band information. Figs. 8 and 9 showed the differences in CO and DCM adsorption at 50 °C for an hour. The supporting information document adds specific reaction conditions. The CO2 species were shown by strong absorption bands (2349, 2360 cm-1) [59] . Fig. 8(b) showed the vibration of multidentate carbonate (p-CO3 2-) at 1420 cm-1 [59]. During CO adsorption, CO reacted with the catalyst, producing CO2. This showed that the catalyst was an effective oxidizer. Fig. 8(c) and Fig. 8(d) showed the tensile vibration of CCl (778, 848, 840 cm-1) [34], both catalysts exhibited peaks of DCM physical adsorption(1200 cm-1)[34] in the pure DCM adsorption process. This indicated that DCM was adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst. Fig.10 (c) and Fig. 8(d) both displayed CO2 bands. Fig. 8(c) showed i-HCO3 -, b-CO3 2- and p-CO3 2-. The vibration of the COO- was shown in Fig. 8(d). DCM could react with the catalyst's lattice oxygen to produce carbonate species and CO2. Fig. 8(d) showed the stretching and vibration of OCH2 O [61] and CO[59]. The catalyst's in-situ infrared spectra for adsorption were displayed in Fig. 9(e) and Fig. 9(f) when DCM and CO were added simultaneously. Fig. 9(e) and Fig. 9(f) showed the oscillations of CO2, CO and CCl. In relation to the adsorbed DCM, the absorption band at 1254 cm-1[62] was a vibration of CH2. The adsorption degree of Cu0.25/MnO2 on DCM was shown to be weaker than that of MnO2 when both CO and DCM was present. This suggested that competitive adsorption was occurring on the catalyst's surface. Fig. 9(g) and Fig. 9(h) showed the substances produced to see how Cl poisoning affected the catalyst. The analysis results of Cu0.25/MnO2 and MnO2 showed consistent characteristic peaks. This indicated that the same reaction mechanism on different catalysts is consistent. CCl vibrations and hydroxyl species emerged during the reaction process. This indicated that chlorinated species were adsorbed on the catalyst surface. The strong absorption band of CO2 generated indicated a violent reaction. The vibration of the formaldehyde species C=O, CH3O- and COO- [63] occurred. At 260 °C, the DCM intermediate oxidized to formaldehyde. Formaldehyde was oxidized to form CH3O- and COO- via the Cannizzaro reaction[64]. Ultimately, it was oxidized to CO2 and H2O in a single step. 3.8.2 Stage catalyst deactivation analysis Fig. 10 showed the staged process of catalyst deactivation through the time-resolved deactivation curve of transient experiments. Stage 1: As electron-rich areas, oxygen vacancies drew Cl atoms to DCM molecules preferentially, creating the first adsorption states [66]. C-Cl signal (778,730cm-1) increased significantly during the first half hour of DCM adsorption on the catalyst, as indicated by the in-situ DRIFT analysis results displayed in Fig. 10(c) and (d). This proved the phenomenon of DCM adsorbing oxygen vacancies through Cl atoms. Transient experiments also revealed partial recovery upon stopping DCM, suggesting that weak chemical or physical adsorption was predominant at this time and that Cl atoms did not establish robust bonds with metals[44]. This related to the time-resolved experiment's initial phase. Stage 2: DCM decomposed to produce Cl-, which formed stable Clmetal species with metals. In Fig. 5(g) and (h), the Cl 2p spectrum revealed a signal peak with a binding energy of 198 eV (Metal Cl bond). In the Mn 2p spectra shown in Fig. 5 (a) to (d) and the data results in Table 2, Cl reduction of the metal was indicated by the decline in the AOS and the Mn4+/Mn3+ ratio. The second stage of the time-resolved experiment showed strong interactions between metals and chlorine species, leading to catalyst deactivation. 3.8.3 Poisoning process and chlorine resistance mechanism Fig. 11 showed the specific poisoning process of the catalyst with and without the introduction of copper. This explained the role of Cu on the active sites and oxygen vacancies of the catalyst during DCM poisoning process. Introducing Cu can slow down the adsorption of chlorine species on active sites and improve the chlorine resistance of MnO2 catalysts by increasing oxygen vacancies. Chlorine species will bind with metal and oxygen vacancies. The introduction of Cu will allow chlorine species to preferentially adsorb on oxygen vacancies, slow down the poisoning of Mn by chlorine species. The XPS Cl 2p spectrum analysis results showed that Clmetal (Binding energy∼198.3 eV) dominates, indicating that Cl species formed strong chemical adsorption bonds with the metal. The Cl/Mn atomic ratio on the surface of Cu MnO2 (1.1 → 0.72), and the Cl-1 dissolution concentration detected by IC also decreased by 63 % (1.24 → 0.47 mg/L), directly confirming that Cu doping could inhibit the irreversible adsorption of chlorine species. Zhao et al. [67]. calculated through density functional theory (DFT) that Cu doping reduced the formation energy of MnO2 oxygen vacancies from 2.78 eV to 2.58 eV, indicating that Cu promoted the generation of oxygen vacancies through electron modulation. Lin et al. [44]. revealed through DFT simulations that the adsorption energy of Cl at oxygen vacancies (-2.95 eV) was significantly lower than its binding strength at four coordinated (-1.30 eV), five coordinated Mn sites (-1.72 eV), and Mn3+ active centers (-2.5 eV). This was highly consistent with the experimental results, indicating that oxygen vacancies preferentially captured Cl species through thermodynamic advantages, forming reversible adsorption states, thereby blocking the toxic pathway of Cl to the active site. From the results of TG-MS, it could be observed that the introduction of Cu could lower the desorption temperature of HCl (79.48 °C → 74.83 °C) and achieve regeneration of oxygen vacancies. 4 Conclusion During the reaction between DCM and lattice oxygen in the α-MnO2, intermediate organic chlorine species and inorganic chlorine species are generated and deposited on the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. HCl is an inorganic chlorine species deposited on the surface of the catalyst. DCM and CO compete for adsorption sites on the catalyst surface, which can lead to deactivation. The Cu-Mn interaction activates more lattice oxygen in Cu0.25/MnO2, thereby improving the oxidation performance at low temperatures. The introduction of Cu increases the number of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst, which increases the CO oxidation active sites and chlorine adsorption sites of the catalyst, thereby making the catalyst more resistant to chlorine in DCM poisoning reactions. The above conclusion has certain guiding significance for exploring the mechanism of CVOC poisoning and improving the chlorine resistance of catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic oxidation of carbon monoxide (CO) by manganese oxide catalysts has always been a research hotspot. In complex sintering flue gas environments, chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) with high toxicity, volatility, and recalcitrance have a significant impact on the CO oxidation activity of catalysts. In this investigation, dichloromethane (DCM) was used as a model pollutant to study the effect of CVOCs on CO catalytic oxidation reaction for the first time. The preparation of Cu0.25/MnO2 using the oxalic acid chelation-assisted hydrothermal method showed the best CO removal efficiency and chlorine resistance. Cu promoted the generation of oxygen vacancies by enhancing electron transfer, which was beneficial for slowing down the adsorption of chlorine species on active sites. The introduction of Cu lowers the desorption temperature of HCl and inhibit the reversible adsorption of chlorine species. Through the use of in-situ DRIFT and other physical and chemical techniques, it was found that the mechanism of catalyst deactivation is staged. (1) Short-term deactivation: DCM adsorbed on oxygen vacancies, temporarily covering the active sites. (2) Long-term deactivation: DCM decomposed to produce chlorine species, which form stable Cl metal species with the metal. The mechanism by which copper doping enhanced the chlorine resistance of catalysts has been clarified, providing new insights into improving the chlorine resistance of catalysts.
